Zone_I.access: Difficult - may require sternotomy, thoracotomy, or clavicular resection

Zone_II.boundaries: Cricoid cartilage to angle of mandible
Zone_II.access: Directly accessible via anterior cervical incision
Zone_II.management: Traditionally - explore if platysma violated; Modern - CTA-directed selective approach

Zone_III.boundaries: Angle of mandible to skull base
Zone_III.management: Imaging before operation; endovascular preferred for arterial injuries

modern.all_zones: CTA for stable patients - guides management
modern.selective_exploration: Based on CTA findings and clinical trajectory
modern.endovascular: Increasing role in Zone I and III injuries

hard_signs: Hemoptysis or air bubbling from wound

workup.CTA: First-line imaging for stable patients - all zones
workup.angiography: For intervention or when CTA inadequate
workup.surgical_exploration: Hard signs, unstable patient, or positive imaging

definition.@value: Classification of the neck into three horizontal zones (I, II, III) based on surgical accessibility, guiding the evaluation and management of penetrating neck trauma.

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Define the three zones of the neck and their boundaries
Identify key structures in each zone
Contrast traditional vs modern management algorithms
Apply zone-based approach to penetrating neck trauma
clinical_pearls: Zone II (cricoid to mandible angle) is ACCESSIBLE - can explore directly
Zone I (thoracic inlet) and Zone III (skull base) are DIFFICULT access - image first
Modern approach: CTA for ALL zones in STABLE patients
Hard signs = immediate OR regardless of zone
Endovascular options have expanded management of Zone I and III injuries
Platysma violation used to mandate exploration - now selective with CTA
